75mm/18 Mod. 35 Howitzer.note: 3 battalions, 3 batteries each (8 howitzers per battalion)

47mm/32 Mod. 35.note: Regimental AT guns distributed across infantry regiments

anti_aircraft.note: 20mm AA guns organic to artillery regiment but count unavailable for 1942-Q4

supply_logistics.supply_status: Strained for both defensive and offensive operations. Primary constraints: fuel shortages, ammunition rationing, extended supply lines from Tripoli (1,800km). Desert conditions causing high vehicle attrition. Water supplies critical issue.

tactical_doctrine.role: Static defensive infantry division. Binary structure (two regiments) provided compact organization suitable for holding fortified positions. Limited mobility due to minimal motorization.
known_issues: Limited anti-tank capability (47mm guns inadequate vs British armor)
Low morale due to extended service in harsh conditions
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Limited - division struggled with desert conditions. Water shortages, inadequate rations, and lack of proper desert equipment affected combat effectiveness.

special_rules: Limited mobility - all movement at infantry speed
Vulnerable to armor - AT guns ineffective vs Grants/Shermans

source: Nafziger Collection: 1st 'Superga' Division North Africa 15 June 1942 (942IFBA.pdf)
US Army G-2 Intelligence: Order of Battle of the Italian Army July 1943

command.commander.name.reason: Commander name not identified in Nafziger June 1942 document or US G-2 July 1943 report for 1942-Q4 timeframe
command.commander.name.mitigation: Check Italian military archives or division histories for commander assignments Q4 1942

anti_aircraft.total.reason: Source mentions '1 Battalion (3 btrys 20mm guns)' but specific gun count per battery not provided. Standard Italian AA battery = 4 guns, suggesting 12 total, but not confirmed.
anti_aircraft.total.estimate_method: If standard Italian AA battery structure (4 guns), total would be 12x 20mm. However, left as 0 pending confirmation.

notes.data_quality: Tier 2 extraction. Primary source (Nafziger June 1942) provides detailed regimental breakdown. Q4 1942 data extrapolated assuming minimal structural changes June-October 1942. Division participated in El Alamein battles during this quarter.
notes.organization: Italian binary division structure with two infantry regiments (91st and 92nd Basilicata). Lighter than German/British divisions. Total strength ~7,200 vs. German divisions ~12,000.
notes.equipment_notes: Limited motorization typical of Italian infantry divisions. 75 trucks total vs. 400+ for German divisions. Horses (528 documented June 1942) remained primary transport. 47mm AT guns inadequate against British Matildas, Grants, and Shermans.
notes.combat_record: Division arrived North Africa June 1942 (1942-Q2). Fought Second Battle of El Alamein October-November 1942 where it suffered heavy casualties. Continued fighting in Tunisia through 1943-Q2 until Axis surrender May 1943.
notes.source_reconciliation: June 1942 Nafziger data shows 91st Regiment at reduced strength (1,088) vs 92nd Regiment (3,560). By October 1942 (Q4), both regiments likely reinforced to more balanced strengths. Estimated 91st: 1,100, 92nd: 3,600 for Q4.
